[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Config: Restart behavior] If the execute() function terminates abnormally, does the validator properly restart the service with correct state, or can crashes leave the validator unable to participate in consensus? (High)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Integration: Error propagation] When SerializerService.handle_message() returns errors at line 53, are these errors properly typed to distinguish network issues from safety rule violations from malicious inputs? (Medium)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Integration: Response handling] Does the serialized response at line 53 include version information or checksums to detect corruption or incompatibility between client and server? (Medium)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: Byzantine validator] Can a Byzantine validator with < 1/3 voting power exploit the remote service to trick an honest validator into signing conflicting votes by sending carefully timed SafetyRulesInput messages? (Critical)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: Network adversary] Can a network-level attacker who can intercept and modify TCP traffic between the client and server manipulate SafetyRulesInput messages to cause safety violations? (Critical)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: Service impersonation] Can an attacker start their own malicious safety-rules service on the same network and trick validators into connecting to it instead of the legitimate service? (Critical)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: Equivocation] Can an attacker exploit race conditions in the remote service to cause a validator to sign two different votes for the same round, enabling double-signing attacks? (Critical)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: Liveness denial] Can an attacker continuously send invalid SafetyRulesInput messages that cause the service to spend all its time processing errors, preventing legitimate consensus operations? (High)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: State rollback] Can an attacker cause the PersistentSafetyStorage to revert to an earlier state by exploiting crashes or error conditions, allowing previously forbidden operations to succeed? (Critical)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Attack: Timeout manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate network conditions to cause timeouts at critical moments, such as when voting or signing proposals, to influence which validator's operations succeed? (High)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Monitoring: Error logging] The warning log at line 43 only logs the error message - does this provide sufficient information to detect and respond to active attacks on the safety-rules service? (Medium)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Monitoring: Success metrics] Does the remote service emit metrics for successful operations, or only for failures, making it difficult to detect subtle attacks that succeed in violating safety rules? (Medium)

[File: consensus/safety-rules/src/remote_service.rs] [Monitoring: Performance] Are there metrics tracking message processing latency at line 42-44, allowing operators to detect if the service is under attack or experiencing degraded performance? (Low)
